Issues.Title: feat: add composition-api
Issues.Body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [x] Feature


**Information**

Bringing [@vue/composition-api](https://github.com/vuejs/composition-api) code to `vue` core.

## TODO

- [ ] ensure the build is working
- [ ] add type testing (similar to vue 3)
- [ ] support for `composition-api` same as the plugin 
- [ ] `setup` should work out-of-box
- [ ] vue 3 typescript types
- [ ] Backporting vue 3 types and tests - changes must be minimal to allow copy&paste in the future.
- [ ] Ensure compatibility with the current v2 types

## Possible improvements by having access to vue 2 reactivity internals

Those are some issue currently the plugin have because we don't have access to some of the internals, it still needs some exploratory work and might not be possible.

- [ ] Prevent `watchEffect` infinite loop https://github.com/vuejs/composition-api/pull/522 
- [ ] `reactive` array  https://github.com/vuejs/composition-api/pull/522 
- [ ] `map` and `set` reactivity similar to `vue-next` https://github.com/vuejs/composition-api/pull/509

Issues.Title: Vue SSR performing bad over time
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/vue](https://codesandbox.io/s/vue)







### Steps to reproduce
I am using Vue SSR for a decent sized application. The problem is the server response time(TTFB) or in this case time taken for the renderToString method is growing over time. Once I restart the server, the values comes back to normal level & then it continues again in an upward trend.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69390751/113185728-6f885780-9274-11eb-9737-ef75f164a230.png)


### What is expected?
Given load, I can understand that the performance could go bad, but it should come back to normal level once done

### What is actually happening?
The time taken to render should not increase linearly over time. 

---
There is not much CPU usage I can see & I tried taking CPU profile snapshot as well, but couldn't able to figure out what would be causing this.

I have been stuck at this problem for days now. Tried various things, nothing is helping out. Please help!!

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Vue SSR performing bad over time" (#11993)

Issues.Title: Incorrect type for AsyncComponentFactory
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/Esurnir/repro-types-vue](https://github.com/Esurnir/repro-types-vue)







### Steps to reproduce
clone the repo and do yarn followed by a yarn serve, open the browser.

The test case is in App.vue

### What is expected?
`MyComponent1` which is a correctly typed `AsyncComponent` should render. It contains a component property which is of type `AsyncComponentPromise` which is a fonction that returns a promise.

`MyComponent2` which is incorrectly typed as `component` is of type `Promise<EsModuleComponent>` should not load properly.

### What is actually happening?
The opposite.

---
This is due to [this line](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/b51430f598b354ed60851bb62885539bd25de3d8/src/core/vdom/helpers/resolve-async-component.js#L122)
which checks wether component is a promise, not a function which returns a promise. 

Among the two ways this could be fixed :
component could be of type `Promise<Component | EsModuleComponent>` instead of the maybe confusingly named AsyncComponentPromise. Or resolveAsyncComponent could have a third case where if res.component is of type Function, it should call res.component(resolve, reject) and test if -that- is a promise before failing.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Incorrect type for AsyncComponentFactory" (#11990)

Issues.Title: `.number` input modifier is removing decimal on user input
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[ https://codepen.io/davegould41/pen/qBRqyRo?editors=101]( https://codepen.io/davegould41/pen/qBRqyRo?editors=101)







### Steps to reproduce
- Create an input element with event modifier `v-model.number="num"`
- try typing .01
- notice it resets the value to 1
- (inputting 0.01 works though)

### What is expected?
If the user enters `.01` the input element should have the value of `.01`

### What is actually happening?
`.number` input modifier is removing decimal on user input

If a user inputs `.01` they the input element will capture as `1`

---
I realize that javascript evaluates `.0` as `0` but this is a common scenario when adding numbers to an input element

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`.number` input modifier is removing decimal on user input" (#11989)

Issues.Title: Number Type Warnings in IE11, caused by Core JS
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.12

### Reproduction link
[https://4pujg.csb.app/](https://4pujg.csb.app/)
[https://vue-vfurgs.stackblitz.io]







### Steps to reproduce
DISCLAIMER: CodeSandbox as well as StackBlitz do not seem to support IE11, which makes it _really_ difficult to provide a link here and fulfill you requirements without me setting up a complete project for you. The gist of both examples: add ie11 to browserslist, let corejs add new es6 number constructor in ie11, see all number validations fail....

DESCRIPTION: Using Webpack 4 to transpile a Vue (2.6.12 in this case) bundle to ES5 like this:

{
	test : /\.js$/,
	include : config.JS_INCLUDES.concat(config.VUE_INCLUDES),
	use : [
		{
			loader : 'babel-loader',
			options : {
				plugins : ['@babel/plugin-transform-runtime'],
				presets : [
					['@babel/preset-env', {
						corejs : 3,
						targets : packageConfig.browserslist,
						useBuiltIns : 'usage'
					}]
				],
				cacheDirectory : true
			}
		}
	]
}

where browserslist includes IE11, results in a bundle in which the Core JS package adds "es.number.constructor", which replaces the constructor for Number in window/global to add ES6 features to the prototype (see here: https://caniuse.com/es6-number and https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/blob/v3.9.1/packages/core-js/modules/es.number.constructor.js#L79).

This causes all Number type prop validations in IE11 to fail, because the constructor is not the native one any more and the validation type handling fails to match a provided number for a property to the constructor installed by core js.

### What is expected?
Vue property validation can handle this case and does not rely on the constructor having a string-parsable name (or handle this special, but common case).

### What is actually happening?
All properties being numbers throw warnings, because the comparison of Number instances being handed to the components do not match the expected form of the replaced constructor.

---
You can circumvent this problem by adding

exclude : ['es.number.constructor']

to the babel preset, but this might break other things and libraries like vue-multiselect have this exact polyfill in their dist code, so this will not cover all cases.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Number Type Warnings in IE11, caused by Core JS" (#11986)

[http://www.kehuowang.com/coursedetails?itemid=326705918479695872](http://www.kehuowang.com/coursedetails?itemid=326705918479695872)







### Steps to reproduce
通过列表页进入详情页，在详情页会进行Dplayer实例化new操作，来进行视频播放，造成全局的input v-mode事件，以及所有原生事件失效，无法输入，无法触发chang事件，input事件，刚开始以为ElementUI的input组件问题，但当我们尝试原生的input写法，发现还是出现那种无法输入的情况。

### What is expected?
我们期望进入这个页面技能播放视频也能，唤起我们的input输入内容

### What is actually happening?
进入页面播放了视频，造成input失效无法使用，只有在不实例化Dplayer组件的情况下input可以使用。

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "在使用vue2.0 element-ui和Dplayer第三方视频插件的时候发生重大bug" (#11979)

Issues.Title: Prop named value is always passed as a string.
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/tornadoalert/pen/rNjVzbd](https://codepen.io/tornadoalert/pen/rNjVzbd)







### Steps to reproduce
Setting the value as prop on a custom element fails. It gets passed as a string [Object Object] instead.

```html
<custom-element :value.prop="message"></custom-element>
```
```js
new Vue({
  el: '#app',

})
```

The :value.prop should be passed as an object

### What is actually happening?

Issues.Title: Ability to disable reactivity to improve performance on destroy
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Destroying N RouterLink at once has a cost of `O((N^2)/2)` due to all RouterLink depend on the singleton [reactive property][route-getter] `$route`. When removing hundreds or thousands of links from the page, this cost is noticeable, especially on slow devices. The goal is a cost of `O(N)`.

Hundreds or thousands of links might seem too much, but sure there might be some cases where it makes sense, like an infinite scroll or some big grids. In many cases [vue-virtual-scroller][vue-virtual-scroller] should solve the general problem, but I think it would be better not to require it as a rule.

Removing the dependency on `$route` means effectively disabling reactivity for the RouterLink and thus all the related features. At this moment, I think the only affected features are the CSS classes to show a link is active.

**Why this cost?**

The singleton `_route` is created for the `_routerRoot` [once][route-react]. At this moment, Vue instantiates a Dep to track writes and reads on this attribute.

Each time a RouterLink is created, its render Watcher detects the `$route` [is accessed][route-render], so that the Watcher adds the Dep to its dependencies (`Watcher.deps`) and the Dep adds the Watcher to its subscribers (`Dep.subs`). This means the `Dep.subs` for `_route` is, at least, as large as the number of rendered RouterLinks.

When the `$route` changes, all the RouterLink are [updated][notify] because they are on the `Dep.subs`.

When destroying all the RouterLink (page change), all the components [teardown][teardown] their watchers, and each watcher have to remove itself from the `Dep.subs`. Removing a single RouterLink's Watcher from the `Dep.subs` costs O(N - i), where `N` is the number of RouterLink and `i` the number of RouterLink already removed.

Generally speaking, the cost of removing N RouterLinks at once is O((N^2)/2).

[watcher]: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/v2.6.12/dist/vue.runtime.esm.js#L4418
[dep]: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/v2.6.12/dist/vue.runtime.esm.js#L701
[notify]: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/v2.6.12/dist/vue.runtime.esm.js#L720
[teardown]: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/v2.6.12/dist/vue.runtime.esm.js#L4601

[route-react]: https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/v3.5.1/dist/vue-router.esm.js#L1299
[route-getter]: https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/v3.5.1/dist/vue-router.esm.js#L1314
[route-render]: https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/v3.5.1/dist/vue-router.esm.js#L1096

[vue-virtual-scroller]: https://github.com/Akryum/vue-virtual-scroller


### What does the proposed API look like?
Adding a `no-reactive` prop on RouterLink should be enough.

The meaning of this prop is effectively disabling reactivity on the current route to improve the overall performance, especially when destroying many RouterLink at once.

As a side effect, this flag turns off any feature that depends on the current route. At this moment, I think the only affected features are related to the CSS classes to show if a link is active or not.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: How to get the props value after route update (beforeRouteUpdate)
Issues.Body:
The `next()` method is used in the beforeRouteUpdate function, and the value of the `props` of the instance has not changed.

But if I jump to a page with the same route, the beforeRouteUpdate function will be called again. At this time, the props value in the from parameter is the updated value.

But I did not update the props value in the from routing page, I think it should be automatically updated by VueRouter.

So my doubt is, why can't I get this updated value?

Issues.Title: Please enter dot notation support for named routes
Issues.Body:
<!--
IMPORTANT: Please use the following link to create a new issue:

  https://new-issue.vuejs.org/?repo=vuejs/vue-router

If your issue was not created using the app above, it will be closed immediately.
-->

Here is a piece of code

```
{ 
 path: '/user/products', 
 name: 'products', 
 component: () => import('../views/user/products/Products.vue'), 
 children: [
   { 
     path: 'list', 
     name: 'list', 
     components: {
     default: () => import('../views/user/products/Products.vue'), 
     products: () => import('../views/user/products/List.vue')
    },
    add...,
    edit...
   },
 ]
},
```

It would just be cool if in a template, I could use it like this

```
<router-link :to="{ name: 'products' }">user products</router-link>
<router-link :to="{ name: 'products.list' }">list</router-link>
<router-link :to="{ name: 'products.add' }">add</router-link>
<router-link :to="{ name: 'products.edit' }">edit</router-link>
```

it was a simple, concise solution, don't you think?

```
<router-link :to="{ name: 'user.products.list' }">user</router-link>
<router-link :to="{ name: 'admin.products.list' }">admin</router-link>
```

???
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Please enter dot notation support for named routes" (#3491)

Issues.Title: Vuex4 - typings for store.getters
Issues.Body:
Forgive me if I'm missing something but it seems that for Vuex4 there is no way to provide typings for our getters, only state. As a result `store.getters` is of type `any` which is not ideal for typescript users.

Is this an intentional design decision?

Issues.Title: Do mutations on next tick
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
When modifying data in the stores I want the action callback to be called before every mutation.
E.g: I'm in a modal and I delete the currently viewed object, I want to call my router.push before the object is effectively deleted.

### What does the proposed API look like?
The new API would not change (in appearance) : all the commits would be applied in a batch after the action is terminated.
The only breaking change would be that we cannot trust the state after the commit but it's not a problem if you call your mutations with data independent of the state (which is a best practice)

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Vuex - watch option in definition - WHY?
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Please do not close this without looking through ALL the links below.

People have asked, but as far as I have read and looked through discussion forums, no one has actually given an answer.

You'll notice that discussions just get closed but always without an answer or meaningful discussion,

https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/issues/1951  
I ask "why this isn't part of the Vuex API", and the answer was "look at #1219". Closed.

Great, I'll take a look!  
https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/issues/1219  
@ralphchristianeclipse asked in 2018, the answer was a question, "What's the practical use case". My answer to that would be it would make Vuex significantly more developer-friendly and make a significantly better developer experience. Which is the reason why Vue was created in the first place - to create a approachable/developer-friendly way to build user interfaces. A bunch of people agreed that the feature would be a good thing. Closed.

https://forum.vuejs.org/t/is-it-possible-to-declare-a-watcher-inside-a-vuex-store/50375  
@mikepatton75 asks if it's possible. The answer is no. Then a bunch of talk about his use-case which didn't need to happen if Vuex just had a watch option, right? Either way, there is no discussion as to WHY the feature isn't available in the Vuex API. So, that's a dead-end as well.

https://forum.vuejs.org/t/vuex-can-i-use-watch-feature-inside-a-vuex-module/75633  
@lwxbr says he does an "extensive workaround" to make a watcher in a store for his use-case, then opens an issue.  But, all he needed was a just simple watcher, right?

https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/issues/1624  
@lwxbr opens the issue. Closed with reference back to #1219 that didn't have an answer.

https://forum.vuejs.org/t/can-a-vuex-module-register-a-watcher-to-watch-its-local-state/8003  
@jri asks if a store can watch its own state, but with an obscurely worded question about a circular file import that is pretty easy to fix with using a 3rd file. But, it never got answered, probably because the question was too obscure? But, perhaps the reason why it was obscure was probably because @jri just needed a simple watcher, but didn't have it, so it was hard to explain the problem in the first place.


### What does the proposed API look like?
Plenty of people have already done this and have been ignored. So, that has proven to be unproductive. I'm simply asking a question "why" and am requesting an answer and/or productive discussion about it so that developers who have the same thought in the future have a productive place to look and understand why Vuex doesn't have a watch option.

Ideally, I'd like to hear from a creator of Vuex with in-depth knowledge about Vuex/Vue as well as the philosophies behind them.

Please do not give just a random answer like, "it's not necessary" because, don't forget, Vue "isn't necessary" either. Let's all use Vanilla! 

I myself am a creator of a UI framework that I designed for beginner developers to learn JavaScript while also making UI frameworks easier to learn later on down the road. I've even taught Vue+Vuex to an entire development team at a company. So, I know how important the core philosophy of a library is.

I have utmost respect for the developers of Vue and Vuex for making such incredible libraries, and I would hope to have that respect reciprocated with an actual productive discussion into this core feature.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Issue with map* with Vuex4, Vue3
Issues.Body:
### Version
4.0.0

### Reproduction link
[https://gitlab.com/engineertdog/vuex-demo-bug](https://gitlab.com/engineertdog/vuex-demo-bug)







### Steps to reproduce
Clone the repo and run. I've included code for the working and non-working portions.

### What is expected?
I would expect that the map* methods in Vuex4 can be utilized in a computed method so that the get/set methods properly execute getters/setters from the store.

While I am using Quasar, as noticed in the simplified demo, using the function returned from mapGetters inside a computed property does not work and throws errors. The same goes for mapActions when used in conjunction with the set function of the computed property.

However, the functions returned from map* work just fine when used inside of the html template.

### What is actually happening?
When using functions returned from map* functions in Vuex4 inside of computed properties (get or set), errors are thrown. The biggest issues seems to be that $this is undefined, but this happens regardless of whether or not arrow functions are used in the computed property.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Is possible to intercept the dispatcher?
Issues.Body:
In my project currently I have around of 400 dispatch and I saw that the big part of that implementation has the same code: 

```
this.$store.dispatch('action', this.payload).catch(e => {
   console.log(e)
    this.$notify.error(e.message)
})
```

So in order to reduce that code I'd like to intercept the dispatcher to throw the error once, and remove the extra code but I'm not sure if it's possible to do that. So just let me know if it's possible or there any other way to do it.

Thanks in advance.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Is possible to intercept the dispatcher?" (#1935)
